intro: Hesperocyparis macrocarpa, commonly known as the giant tamarack, is a coniferous tree native to the western United States. It belongs to the cypress family (Cupressaceae) and is characterized by its long, slender needles and distinct cones. The tree typically grows in moist, well-drained soils along streams and in mountainous regions. Its bark is reddish-brown and peels in thin, fibrous strips. Hesperocyparis macrocarpa is valued for its ecological role in providing habitat and stabilizing stream banks.
